body: @blackdrag I want to be able to get a hold of all symbols within a `CompilationUnit`, including locally declared variables. I don't think there is currently a way of doing this? I am building a groovy [language server](https://github.com/Microsoft/language-server-protocol/), which implements features like search all workspace symbols, auto complete, goto definition, find all references, etc.

Main goal was to allow a way to make `JsonOutput` configurable while not changing the existing static methods and at the same time try to not duplicate too much code or provide too confusing a way to provide the options.  All feedback welcome.

The second commit `Serialization options for JsonOutput` is best viewed by itself and by excluding whitespace by adding `-w` at the git diff command line or `w=1` in the GitHub querystring.

Trying to address the following JIRA tickets with this:

GROOVY-6699: JSON slurper ability to ignore propertie/field names (at least the serializing part)
GROOVY-6854: JsonOutput should be configurable with ISO 8601 UTC time zone instead of GMT
GROOVY-7682: JsonBuilder or JsonOutput incompatible with JodaTime (for now via a closure converter)
GROOVY-7780: JSONBuilder/JSONSlurper: Option to Only Include NonNull values
GROOVY-7858: Make JsonBuilder configurable to not write entries with null values

I merged this but kept the behavior from master of throwing CCE in a place you were throwing a GRE. I changed the test accordingly. Let me know if you think this is okay from your side. I'll look at PR#151 next.

I cannot remember if there was a specific reason for me to choose GRE at the time. Probably should have commented.

I guess at the time I noticed the default CCE gives no useful information, so my intent was probably to provide the user with more details of the failure. At the time I must have experimented a lot with corner-case ranges and noticed the default CCE does not contain enough information.
I understand now that this is also an API change and there are performance implications in creating new Exceptions.

So relying on the default CCE should be better from a technical perspective, even if the generated message is sadly not very useful.

Actually, reading the JIRA issue, I remember this was more than just about the message details. I considered the throwing of a CCE a glitch, meaning un undesired undocumented leaking Exception that confronts Users with the internals of Groovy.

This test code shows the problem:

```
shouldFail(ClassCastException) {
        compareTo(1, "22")
}
```

The question here is whether Groovy as a language **wants** to throw a CCE when the user tries to compare a number and that String, or whether Groovy wants to throw a GRE, as it does for several other error cases. The problem is that the user does not know or care about types he passes to compareTo(), since compareTo is so mighty flexible in comparing apples and oranges in many cases. A CCE should possibly only be thrown if the documentation clearly states that a cast will happen, of that such an Exception will be thrown. Also a CCE may look like a Groovy bug to many users (missing instanceof check before a cast, bad type handling). A GRE looks more like intended behavior.

I think I presumed that the original author of the code had overseen the possibility of a CCE here and did not wrap it out of oversight.

I am somewhat dispassionate about keeping the CCE or using a GRE in the future. I believe semantically the CCE is not desirable for users, both in terms of the message and in terms of the exception type. But I may be wrong, users might actually want to compare all items in a set to check that they are compareTo() compatible, and rely on the CCE to detect pairs that are not compatible.

So with that explanation, I'll let you decide.
for completeness sake: Using an IllegalArgumentException could be a viable third alternative to CCE and GRE, with reasonable semantics.
PR merged, thanks!
PR merged
I think a more informative exception would be preferred (probably a GRE). I'll think about making such a change and it's impacts.

Proposed additional changes:
https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/372

I tried to fix the resolve call but had no luck.  I will close this since it's not an area I'm familiar with and not sure what the desired bytecode should look like for a closure shared variable vs one that isn't.

Haven't been here in a while, but I just want to comment here regarding how my use case looks now with more context. In particular, I want to have a job runner which executes scripts loaded dynamically; the job runner should provide Groovy on classpath and provide a clean execution slate to each script as it comes in, for statelessness.

Thinking back to this bug, it seems like the current way metaclass is implemented will cause any metaclass modifications in the script to "build up" over time, particularly modifications to base classes. Is this intended, that changing a metaclass constitutes "static state" from Groovy's perspective? Or could we have the notion of a GroovyRuntime instance encapsulating state for execution of one (or more related) scripts, but which can be swapped for a new, fresh instance when desired.

Not sure which way to go makes more sense, but would be interested in a word from Groovy expert folks about whether metaclass manipulation is considered "permanent static modification" or "contextual static modification", with replaceable context. Maybe we could support both in a Groovy 3.0? 😛 

EDIT: There's also an element of thread-safety here, which adds to what I'm thinking about. Currently, if I understand correctly, metaclass modifications are visible across threads, causing (potentially unexpected) behavior. If that is the case, I'm OK with the fix as is (default weak metaclass) and recommending my users to avoid all metaclass manipulation, but want to make sure I'm understanding this correctly.
I removed the slightly flawed attempts at synchronization and adopted a more Java behavior when calling next by throwing a NoSuchElementException once a NumberRange iterator is exhausted.

For failing tests which are supposed to pass, the general pattern is to use `GroovyTestCase#notYetImplemented` method or the `@NotYetImplemented` annotation and leave `shouldCompile` in the test itself. This indicates we actually want it to pass but haven't implemented it yet. Also, it would be great to update the Numbers section of `core-syntax.adoc` and add in references to the tags you've added and potentially one or more lines from the passing test too. We'd need to comment out the doco until it is implemented but better that than having a dangling reference.
Actually, the unimplemented cases are cases that I want to fail, but don't. But I get your point.
@baybatu is this PR good to go? :)
Merged (finally!!), thanks!
I'll try to look at this again shortly. I've forgotten where we got up to. Any chance of a rebase and removal of the commits from PR#96? Thanks.
Rebased. Jochen had comments at: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7563
@paulk-asert could you please take a look? :)

It seems Jochen agrees with all changes. He had a concern about exceptions appearing - but really it is only the Classname@hashCode that appears which is what we do now. I am leaning that way as well.
All commits merged. Thanks!

I merged this PR but tweaked to exclude changes to these files:

```
src/main/groovy/util/ClosureComparator.java
src/main/org/codehaus/groovy/antlr/LexerFrame.java
src/main/org/codehaus/groovy/control/CompilePhase.java
src/main/org/codehaus/groovy/runtime/ProcessGroovyMethods.java
src/main/org/codehaus/groovy/runtime/metaclass/MetaMethodIndex.java
subprojects/groovy-groovydoc/src/main/java/org/codehaus/groovy/tools/groovydoc/ClasspathResourceManager.java
subprojects/groovy-groovydoc/src/main/java/org/codehaus/groovy/tools/groovydoc/MockOutputTool.java
subprojects/groovy-groovydoc/src/main/java/org/codehaus/groovy/tools/groovydoc/SimpleGroovyExecutableMemberDoc.java
subprojects/groovy-json/src/main/java/groovy/json/internal/ValueList.java
subprojects/groovy-sql/src/main/java/groovy/sql/CallResultSet.java
```

For those files a package-private field was made final in a non-private class. These all break binary compatibility. For some of the internal `org.codehaus.groovy` classes we _might_ decide to do that but it should be on a case-by-case basis, not in the same commit as the non-controversial changes.
I'd be interested in opinions as to whether the LexerFrame class should be moved to the groovy-console module?
It's only used in the console anyway, I believe, so it sounds a good idea to move it in the console module to me.
It has only been standalone so far - in fact I had forgotten it existed until I was reminded again just recently. This PR hooks it into the console.

PR merged, thanks! Just as a side comment, it is usually a good idea to create a Jira issue to track such changes (as well as the PR). I created one this time here: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7894
Thanks again.
PR merged, thanks! Sorry it took so long. As a comment, it is best to keep formatting changes as a separate commit - it speeds up reviewing the real change(s).

you can find all lists and  to subscribe to them on http://groovy-lang.org/mailing-lists.html Using nabble is also possible, but has sometimes problems. It is better to do it directly

snapshot builds are on the teamcity CI server:
http://ci.groovy-lang.org/project.html?projectId=Groovy
just click on any of the builds with an "Artifacts" link.

Looks really good, nice work.

Just my opinion, but I would not introduce the additional public API alternatives for  equals/hashCode until a need presents itself.  I think the doc in there stating instances of the class are not good candidates for hashed keys is good and sufficient.
Forgot to ask if it would be worthwhile to add `@since` tags on the new IntRange method and on the NumberRange class.
I added in some Map methods which suffered the same problem
Yes, those additional methods do kind of represent possible premature feature introduction. I'll remove them (or at least comment them out) and I'll add the @since tags too.
I removed the groupBy changes and inlined a few lines instead.
The relevant commit was merged - the others were ignored. Thanks.
These tests pass in master, looks like this was fixed in commit a258a3d026ebefc411797b2f69915fe1860262db.  So I went ahead and merged as is so we have tests to cover the invalid ranges.  Thanks.

I like your idea of avoiding the infinite loop but I am not sure of your proposed fix. I think we should either provide an iterator-backed implementation and "leave" the infinite loop which would allow:
`assert [ 1, 2, 3 ].collate( 2, 0 ).take(2) == [[1, 2], [1, 2]]`
or alternatively throw an `IllegalArgumentException` (or an extra flag to toggle the behaviors).
I added a test case, and the missing leftShift/rightShift variants and committed this.

@paulk-asert I totally agree with you. I think we could create a `collateStream` new method that provides an iterator-backed implementation and I think we shouldn't mistake with `collate` method (for many reasons, p.e. backward compatibility). I created the implementation that uses `IllegalStateExeception` when occurs zeroed step. What do you think? 3ed1c5c

Looks good. I am unsure what we'd call an iterator-backed implementation, but it would be a method returning an iterator, not the current methods which do an eager calculation of the result, so what you have makes sense for the current ones.
PR merged, thanks!

@paulk-asert I think this PR was closed. It's normal and this PR will merge afterwards? 😃 

thks.

@blackdrag Hi! After some more testing I realized that this doesn't really expose method declared variables. The map only contains method parameters. Any idea why this is the case? How can I access a method's Variable nodes? I create a Jira issue, which has more detail: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7903
+1 (with just a few minor comments)
is this the correct branch to raise PR to? or should i raise it to master first time raising PR to groovy repo not sure about the branching strategy.
PRs are normally best raised against master
Ok, i am going to raise this one on master.

Now calculating hash code of IntRange by taking only upper and lower bounds into consideration. This means that two IntRanges with same lower and upper bounds have same hash code irrespective of the step. will that be a problem? should i also consider the step during calculation?
This is way faster than iterating through whole collection.

I think this would work ok.  Since step is not used in `equals(IntRange)` I don't think it needs to be considered.  Not much harm in returning the same hashCode for non-equal objects, as long as the same hashCode is returned when two IntRange's are `equal(IntRange)` it should be ok.
+1. I have "impossible cast" pending in another PR but I can easily remove it

Agreed that step isn't a problem. I would have expected that one of reverse or inclusive would have impacted something but looking into it, I don't think they do, so I think the change is all good. I'll have to think a bit more about test coverage but +1 from me in any case. If someone gets around to committing before I get some more time to think about what else might be required, I can always add more after the fact.
PR merged, thanks!
Is there anything in the way of merging this? We're doing something quite similar using reflection and it improves the memory leak situation dramatically.
what needs to be done to merge this is, remove the demo test case and resolve the small merge conflict
I removed the demo test case and rebased.  I made a slight change using try/finally to ensure the clean method is called if the script causing an exception.
Proposed PR merged
One of the commits is unnecessary. So I am gonna close this PR and open a new one.

Thanks! More tests are always a good thing. :smile:

+1

I think with this change it would miss a default `getAt` method on an interface.  I don't think it's a real issue since it would be very edge case-y and I don't think there's much support now for default/static interface methods, just mentioning it.
Cédric, do you have any stats from your experiments with gradle on how frequently asBoolean(Object) is called? Just curious from a "favor correctness ahead of premature optimizations" point of view.

This PR fixes the mentioned problem and frees up `this` as the target of an assignment for the purposes of DSLs and @Category classes but I noticed that outside those use cases we treat assignment of `this` as a NOP:

```
this = ''
println this
```

With or without @CompileStatic. I'll raise that as another issue since I believe we should treat that as some kind of error.

OK, I'll have a think about that possibility and check whether https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7037 and https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-6182 are related too. My inclination is to treat those as separate issues if more work is required.

@melix, thanks for the feedback.  Fair point about performance there would definitely be some cost to this and I can image quite a few loops using `if (somevar)` in place of a null check.  I can implement in a `groovy-jdk8` sub-project but am not sure the issue warrants the added complexity to the build and raising the minimum build jdk to 8.  Would be interested to know what others think.  Might be best to defer this until a later time unless we are ready now to move to 8 for build.
Closing this PR, too bad.
Merged.
This PR should now do all methods and also @Field annotated variable definitions within scripts.
PR applied to master and the 2_4_X branch. Thanks!

+1

I thought maybe there'd be a potential stackoverflow problem by not also passing the visited Set in the recursive calls, but seems as if interface cycles are detected before this point so looks good.
Thanks!
Will close this and wait until we have 8 for the min build version.
Could this please be merged then?

@jochenberger is your issue with `Eval` or more generally `GroovyShell`?

My hesitation with this as it is now is as Jochen pointed out, this doesn't handle scripts that contain class definitions so is not really a good fix, just a bandaid.  Also, I need to do more testing but this may cause problems if metaclasses are touched in the scripts.  I think it would be safe to do this in `Eval` since it doesn't save the shell between invocations, so eval can grab the shell's `GroovyClassLoader` and flush the caches for all the loaded classes.
Any suggestions for debugging Travis failure? It works locally.

I compile and `run()` script classes manually. When compiling, I keep track of the classes that are generated for a script and manually unload them using `InvokerHelper.removeClass()` afterward. Then I have to use reflection to remove them from `globalClassSet`/`globalClassValue`. So what I really need from this PR is the added `ClassInfo.remove()` method and its being called from `InvokerHelper.removeClass()`.
